sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application enables you to perform the following actions:

listitem.para: View a file in ASCII or hexadecimal format simultaneously.
Edit a file in either ASCII or hexadecimal format.

sect2.title: To Open a File
sect2.para: To open a file, choose File Open . Select the file that you want to open, then click OK.
When you open a file in &app;, the application displays the file in the following window.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of main window with an open file

sect2.para: The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: A menubar. The menus on the menubar contain all the commands that you need to work with files in &app;.
A display pane on the left side of the window. This pane displays a hexadecimal view of the file.
A display pane on the right side of the window. This pane displays an ASCII view of the file.

A cursor offsets column. The cursor offset is the distance between the beginning of the file and the first byte in each line. By default, &app; displays the cursor offsets column to the left of the hexadecimal view.

sect2.para: You can open multiple files in &app;. The way in which &app; displays multiple files depends on the Multiple Document Interface (MDI) setting in the Preferences dialog. GNOME supports the following MDI modes:

listitem.para: This mode displays one file at a time in the application window. The application adds a tab for each open file to the window. To display another open file, click on the tab that corresponds to the file. To create a new &app; window for each file that is open, drag the tab corresponding to each file to the desktop.
This mode starts a new window for each file that you open and layers the windows on the desktop.
This mode displays one file at a time in the application window. To display another open file in the window, choose File filename , where filename is the name of the file that you want to display.

sect2.para: See Settings for more information about how to set the MDI mode for &app;.

sect2.title: To Edit a File
sect2.para: To edit a file, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click in the hexadecimal or ASCII view of the file. The view in which the cursor is active displays a full cursor. The view in which the cursor is not active displays an outline of the cursor.
Use any of the following methods to move the cursor around the file:
Scroll through the file using the scrollbar on the window or the arrow keys on the keyboard.
Choose Edit Goto Byte , type the cursor offset as a decimal or hexadecimal value, then click OK. The format of the hexadecimal value must be 0x followed by the offset, for example 0x3.
Edit the ASCII format in the same way you edit a normal text file. Edit the hexadecimal format using the values 0 to 9 and a to f.

sect2.para: To insert data without overwriting existing data, choose Edit Insert mode .

sect2.title: To Save a File
sect2.para: You can save a file in the following ways:

listitem.para: To save changes to the current file, choose File Save .
To save the current file under a new file name, choose File Save As . Enter a name for the file in the Select a file to save buffer as dialog, then click OK.

sect2.title: To Find Data in a File
sect2.para: To search a file for a hexadecimal or ASCII string, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Edit Find .
In the Find Data dialog, choose one of the following options:
Type the string that you want to find.
Click Find Next.

sect2.title: To Find and Replace Data in a File
sect2.para: To search a file for a hexadecimal or ASCII string and then replace the string, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Edit Replace .
In the Find & Replace Data dialog, choose one of the following options:
In the first text box, type the string that you want to find.
In the second text box, type the string that you want to use to replace the string that you find.
Click Find Next.
Click Replace to replace the current occurrence of the string or click Replace All to replace all occurrences of the string.

sect2.title: To Add or Remove Additional Views of a File
sect2.para: To add another view of the current file to your &app; window or to the desktop, choose View Add View . This option is only available if the Multiple Document Interface (MDI) setting in the Preferences dialog is Notebook or Toplevel. See Settings for more information about the Preferences dialog.
To remove a view of the current file, choose View Remove View . If you remove the last view of the file, choose Files filename to view the file again, where filename is the name of the file.

sect2.title: To Export the &app; Display to HTML
sect2.para:
To export the data contained in the &app; window to HTML, choose File Save As HTML . Choose a directory and specify a file name for the HTML file, then click OK. &app; implements the following actions:
Creates a separate HTML file for each page of data that is displayed in the &app; window.
Uses the HTML file name that you specify as the basis for the file name.
Appends a page number to the file name to differentiate the files.
For example, if you specify the file name log.html, &app; creates a series of HTML files named log00000000.html, log00000001.html, log00000002.html, and so on.

sect2.title: To View Data Conversions
sect2.para: To display the binary, decimal, hexadecimal, and ASCII conversions for up to four bytes of data, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Tools Base Converter .

Type the data that you want to convert in one of the fields in the Base Converter dialog and press Return. &app; updates the values of the other fields to display the data conversions. Alternatively, to display the conversions for the data at the cursor position in the current file, click on the Get cursor value button.

sect2.title: To View a Character Table
sect2.para: To view a table that contains the ASCII, hexadecimal, decimal, octal, and binary representations for the values 0 to 255, choose Tools Character Table .

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para: The Preferences dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para: Use this spin box to specify the maximum number of edits that you can undo using the Undo menu item on the Edit menu.
Default: 100.

term.guilabel: Show cursor offset in statusbar as

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to select the format in which the cursor offset is displayed. The format can be decimal, hexadecimal, or a custom print style string that only contains the format specifiers x, o, and s.
Default: Hexadecimal.
Select this option to display the cursor offsets in a column to the left of the hexadecimal view of the &app; window.
Default: selected.

Click on this button to display the font selector dialog. Use the font selector dialog to edit the existing font information or type new font information. Specify a font type, style, and size for displaying the contents of files in &app;, then click OK. The font information that you specify is displayed on the Font button.
Default: Courier 12
Select how the application displays the hexadecimal content of a file in the &app; window. The options are as follows:
Bytes - single bytes.
Words - groups of two bytes.
Longwords - groups of four bytes.
Default: Bytes.

sect2.title: MDI

listitem.para: Select the MDI mode in which to display multiple files in &app;. The options are as follows:
Select this option to use the MDI mode that is specified in the Control Center as the MDI mode for &app;. The default MDI mode can be any one of the MDI modes that GNOME supports.
Default: Modal.

sect2.para: See Getting Started for more information about the MDI modes that are available for &app;.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify the paper size to use when you print files from &app;.
Default: A4.
Use this spin box to specify the width of the paper to use for printing. Use the drop-down list box to the right of the Width spin box to specify the unit for the width and height of the paper.
Default: 8.3 and Inch.
Use this spin box to specify the height of the paper to use for printing.
Default: 11.7.
Click on this button to set the paper size to the value specified in your system settings.
Click on the Data font button to specify the size of the font to use to print the data contained in a file.
Default: Courier 10.0.
Click on the Header font button to specify the size of the font to use to print the header information that is contained in the file.
Default: Helvetica 12.0.
Use this spin box to specify the number of lines that &app; prints with a surrounding shaded box. If the value of the spin box is 10, &app; prints the first 10 lines of the file within a shaded box.
Default: 0.
